## Housing Price in 2025

1. Use `paste()` and for-loop to create a character vector `date_2025` that contains 365 days in 2025, and each date repeat 3 times. i.e., `c("2025-01-01", "2025-01-01", "2025-01-01", ..., "2025-12-31")`

::: {.callout-tip title="Hint"}
Use `if (month %in% vec)` to check if there are 28, 30 or 31 days in that month.
:::


2. Use `as.Date()` to convert the `date_2025` as type `date`.

3. Create a numeric vector `housing_price` with length 1095 having the value generated from a normal distribution with `mean = 10000`, `sd = 2000`.

4. Combine `date_2025` and `housing_price_2025` as a new dataframe `housing_2025`.

5. Use `geom_line()` with `linewidth = 0.3` to plot the average housing price for each date in 2025.


``` r
set.seed(2025)

library(tidyverse)

date_2025 <- c()

for (month in 1:12){
  if (month %in% c(1, 3, 5, 7, 8, 10, 12)){
    for (day in 1:31){
      temp <- replicate(n = 3, expr = paste("2025", month, day, 
                                            sep = "-")
                        )
      date_2025 <- c(date_2025, temp)
    }
  }
  else if (month %in% c(4, 6, 9, 11)){
    for (day in 1:30){
      temp <- replicate(n = 3, expr = paste("2025", month, day, 
                                            sep = "-")
                        )
      date_2025 <- c(date_2025, temp)
    }    
  }
  else{
    for (day in 1:28){
      temp <- replicate(n = 3, expr = paste("2025", "2", day, 
                                            sep = "-")
                        )
      date_2025 <- c(date_2025, temp)
    }        
  }
}

date_2025 <- as.Date(date_2025)

housing_price_2025 <- rnorm(n = 1095, mean = 10000, sd = 2000)

housing_2025 <- data.frame(date = date_2025,
                           price = housing_price_2025
                           )

ggplot(housing_2025, aes(x = date, y = price)) + 
    geom_line(stat = "summary", 
              fun = "mean", 
              linewidth = 0.3, 
              color = "steelblue"
              )
```
